contextId.information: The Israelites will not speak the names of Baal and the idols again. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For I will remove the names of the Baals from her mouth

contextId.information: Here "David" represents all the descendants of David. AT: "a descendant of David to be their king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "trembling" represents feelings of awe and humility. AT: "they will come back to Yahweh and will humble themselves, honor him, and ask for his blessings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: they will come trembling before Yahweh and his goodness

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "honor" is a metonym that represents Yahweh, and "shame" is a metonym that represents idols. AT: "They have stopped worshiping me, their honorable God, and now worship shameful idols" or 2) some Bible versions translate this as "I will exchange their honor for shame." This means Yahweh will take away the things which the priests honor and cause the priests to be ashamed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: They exchanged their honor for shame

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this refers to Adam, the first man or 2) this is a metonym that represents the people who live in a city in Israel called Adam. AT: "Like the people in the city of Adam" or 3) this refers to people in general. The word "Adam" means "man" or "humankind." AT: "Like all of humankind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Footprints of blood" probably represents the evildoers and their acts of murder. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Gilead is a city ... with footprints of blood

contextId.information: Here "tongue" refers to what the officials say. AT: "because they insult me" or "because they curse me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: because of the insolence of their tongues

contextId.information: King Jeroboam the Second of Israel (See [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:12:28]]) had made two golden idols that looked like calves and set them up so the people of his kingdom would worship it. Yahweh is speaking of their worship as if it were the calves themselves. AT: "You because you worship your calf idol" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The unclean food is spoken of as if it were able to go places by itself. Of course, people actually had to take it with them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: it will not come into the house of Yahweh

contextId.information: Yahweh is stating that he will force Israel out of his land, the land of Canaan. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will drive them out of my house

contextId.information: Here "sword" represents the enemies of Israel who will destroy Israel's cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The sword will fall on their cities

contextId.information: Here "heart" represents God's will and decisions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My heart has changed within me

contextId.information: The people of the southern kingdom are still loyal to God. Here "going about with me" represents being together with God. However, many versions have different interpretations of this difficult passage. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: But Judah is still going about with me

contextId.information: Here "Ephraim" represents all the people of Israel. Also "wind" represents something that is useless or temporary. The people of Israel doing things that will not help them is spoken of as if they eat the wind. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Hosea uses the term "Ephraim" to refer to the entire northern kingdom, although it was also the name of one of the ten tribes. Hosea seems to be speaking of a long-past time, when the northern kingdom was strong and honored, unlike at the present time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

What a person says is called the fruit of his lips. AT: "our words and songs of praise." Modern versions have different translations of this difficult passage. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
